doc.title: Indonesia Equity Strategy
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/Indonesia Equity Strategy Maintaining Cautious Stance Amid Protests and Policy Stimulus Maintaining Cautious Stance Amid_2025-08-31

passages.text: Maintaining Cautious Stance Amid Prettests and Policy Stimulus

Indonesia's protests over the past week, sparked by grievances including anger over Rp50m/month housing allowances for lawmakers, have hit its financial markets - weakening the rupiah and pushing bond yields up. With unemployment remaining high and layoffs seen across industries, the ongoing protests risk further hurting consumer and business sentiment. Big companies are unlikely to spend much on capex in 2H25, based on our channel checks. However, fiscal spending is set to accelerate, focusing on social programs, while Bl could cut rates (3 x 25bps) through January 2026, according to our economist. Danantara's Rp50trn (US\(3.1bn) Patriot Bond program aims at attracting offshore Indonesian money to fund domestic energy and AI projects, incentivizing it with tax amnesty. We maintain our cautious view on the market, preferring defensives BBCA, GOTO, BRIS, ASII, ICBP, and commodity names MDKA and ADMR given the market's relatively low valuation of 11.5x forward P/E.

Protests hurting market sentiment and business confidence: Indonesia has been witnessing widespread protests since August 25, 2025, triggered by public anger over grievances including lawmakers' monthly housing allowance (c. Rp50m/month) that is being perceived by protesters as lavish. The tragic death of a delivery rider in Jakarta further escalated nationwide protests. In Greater Jakarta, protesters stormed government buildings and ransacked three parliament members' houses as well as that of Finance Minister Sri Muljani over the weekend. While markets reacted on Friday to the protests, with the Jakarta Composite Index sliding 1.5- 2.3%, the rupiah weakening 0.8- 0.9% and bond yields widening, we believe negative reactions will persist near- term.

Weak growth and demonstrations could further pressure business activities: Indonesia's overall economy has been weak. The unemployment rate is rising and hiring remains concentrated in informal, low- quality roles, particularly outside modern sectors. Fixed manufacturing jobs are in decline, shedding more than 42,000 positions in 1H25, signaling in our view de- industrialization and weaker wage growth. The protests risk further hurting consumer and business confidence, potentially weighing on retail sales, lending, and private- sector investment. The middle- class - already suffering from inflation and job insecurity - appears increasingly squeezed. Our conversations with Indonesian corporates suggest that they remain cautious and are unlikely to meaningfully expand capex in the medium- term.

Better fiscal and lower rates should be expected in 2H25E: In response to sluggish growth and mounting household strain, we expect the government to double down on spending, especially on such social programs as the free meals initiative,

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

subsidized housing and regional infrastructure, aiming to shore up demand and employment. Our economist expects Bank Indonesia to continue its dovish cycle with further rate cuts to nurture recovery (3 x 25bps cuts until Jan- 26). Although easing should support liquidity and banks' cost of funds, winning back investor confidence is vital to preventing capital flight and protecting financial conditions.

Issuance of Patriot Bond: Danantara, Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund, is due to issue Patriot Bonds totaling Rp50trn (US \(3.1bn) with a 2% coupon and 5- 7 years tenor aimed at financing waste- to- energy and AI projects. We expect the bonds to attract Indonesian money parked overseas and will be likely aligned with tax amnesty frameworks, which could expand participation by wealthy Indonesians conglomerates - potentially blending patriotic appeal with contribution to the nation.

Maintaining cautious stance: Amid the protests, economic woes and fiscal strain, we maintain our cautious stance on Indonesian equities, favoring defensive names with likely lower downside risks such as BBCA, GOTO, BRIS, ASII, and ICBP, and commodity- related plays (MDKA, ADMR) that offer earnings resilience and lower sensitivity to swings in sentiment. We believe the market could see further downside this week in the face of escalating protests. That said, the Indonesian market is trading at what we think is a low valuation of 11.5x one- year forward P/E, close to 2SD below its historical mean.

Alamtri Minerals Indonesia (ADMR.JK; Rp1005.0; 1; 29 Aug 25; 16:00) | Astra International (ASII.JK; Rp5500.0; 1; 29 Aug 25; 16:00) | Bank Central Asia (BBCA.JK; Rp8075.0; 1; 29 Aug 25; 16:00) | Bank Syariah Indonesia (BRIS.JK; Rp2710.0; 1; 29 Aug 25; 16:00) | GoTo Gojek Tokopedia (GOTO.JK; Rp58.0; 1H; 29 Aug 25; 16:00) | Indofood CBP (ICBP.JK; Rp8975.0; 1; 29 Aug 25; 16:00) | Merdeka Copper Gold (MDKA.JK; Rp2470.0; 1; 29 Aug 25; 16:00)

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of \(15\%\) or more or \(25\%\) or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "–" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds \(15\%\) against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.

For the purposes of disclosing recommendations other than for equity (whose definitions can be found in the corresponding disclosure sections), "Buy" means a positive directional trade idea; "Sell" means a negative directional trade idea; and "Relative Value" means any trade idea which does not have a clear direction to the investment strategy.

The yield and average life of CMOs (collateralized mortgage obligations) referenced in this Product will fluctuate depending on the actual rate at which mortgage holders prepay the mortgages underlying the CMO and changes in current interest rates. Any government agency backing of the CMO applies only to the face value of the CMO and not to any premium paid. Forecasts are not a guarantee or reliable indicator of future performance. Card Insights. Where this report references Card Insights data, Card Insights consists of selected data from a subset of Citi's proprietary credit card transactions. Such data has undergone rigorous security protocols to keep all customer information confidential and secure; the data is highly aggregated and anonymized so that all unique customer identifiable information is removed from the data prior to receipt by the report's author or distribution to external parties. This data should be considered in the context of other economic indicators and publicly available information. Further, the selected data represents only a subset of Citi's proprietary credit card transactions due to the selection methodology or other limitations and should not be considered as indicative or predictive of the past or future financial performance of Citi or its credit card business.
